title-group.article-title: De Laude Psalmorum and Ælfwine’s Prayerbook: A Quotation from a Carolingian Psalm Devotional in a Late Anglo-Saxon Programme for Morning Prayer

body.p: A large number of Latin and English prayers, apparently intended for private use, can be found in Anglo-Saxon monastic manuscripts.1 It can often be difficult to tell in which context these prayers were said. However, a few prayers and prayer programmes give very clear guidelines for use, instructing the reader in when and where to pray, which prayers and psalms to say, and why it is important to say them. One of the most interesting of these texts is a short guide to prayer found on a single leaf of the eleventh-century Winchester manuscript known as Ælfwine’s Prayerbook. Of particular significance is the fact that this Old English text contains a short, carefully translated excerpt from De laude psalmorum, a Carolingian treatise on praying for one’s personal needs using the words of the psalms. The presence of this hitherto unnoticed quotation in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook suggests that De laude psalmorum was not only being read in late Anglo-Saxon England, but was also being accurately translated into the vernacular language, and used to create a wholly new programme for morning prayer.

Ælfwine’s Prayerbook is the name given, by their editor Beate Günzel, to the manuscripts London, British Library Cotton Titus D. xxvii and xxvi.2 These are believed to have originally been a single codex,3 a personal compendium belonging to Ælfwine, Dean of the New Minster in Winchester, which explicitly names its owner in several places and describes him as a ‘decanus’ (‘dean’).4 Neil Ker therefore dates the composite manuscript to after 1023 and no later than 1035, the year in which Ælfwine became the abbot of New Minster.5 Although most of its texts were copied by two main scribes, Ælfwine’s Prayerbook also contains a further nine hands,6 including some which may date from a little after Ælfwine’s use of the manuscript, and the work of a twelfth-century female glossator.7 The manuscript contains a wide variety of texts, encompassing computus, prognostics, scientific knowledge, Ælfric of Eynsham’s De temporibus anni, prayers, Special Offices, a collectar, and three devotional miniatures.8 Alicia Corrêa has suggested that Ælfwine may have carried this manuscript when officiating at services on external estates owned by the New Minster, a role which, as D. H. Turner notes, was included amongst the duties of a dean.9

Ælfwine’s Prayerbook includes many texts which were suitable for private prayer,10 but potentially the most interesting of these is a list of instructions for morning prayer found on Titus D. xxvi, fol. 2r–v, which Günzel titles ‘Directions for Private Devotions’. This text gives a clear indication not only of which prayers an eleventh-century Winchester monk or nun may have used, but also of when, how, and why he or she said them. It was not written in one of the two hands responsible for most of the manuscript’s texts, but in what Günzel has named Hand F, which Ker suggests may date from after Ælfwine’s use of the prayerbook.11 In full, the text reads as follows:
Ælce sunnandæg bebeod þe ðære þrynnesse naman, þæt is fæder 7 sunu 7 se halga gast.
7 sing ‘benedicite’ 7 ‘Gloria in excelsis Deo’ 7 ‘credo in Deum’ 7 ‘pater noster’ Criste to lofe, þonne gelimpð þe ealle wucan þe bet.
Mihtest þu gewunian þæt ðu hit sunge ælce dæge, þonne ðu ærest onwoce.
7 cweþ ðonne God ælmihtig, ‘For þinre miclan mildheortnesse 7 for ðissa godes worda mægne, miltsa me, 7 syle me minra gedonra synna forgyfnesse, 7 ðara toweardra gescildnessa, 7 þine bletsunga to eallum þingum 7 huru minre sawle reste on ðam ecan life 7 a ðine miltse.’
7 geþenc ælce frigedæge, þæt ðu strecce þe on eorðan godes þances, 7 sing ‘DEVS misereatur nostri.’ [Psalm 66]
7 do þis dihlice, þær ðu sylf sy.
7 geþenc þæt he ðrowode on þone dæg micel for eall mancyn.
Ne mæg ænig mann on his agen geþeode þa geswinc 7 þara costnunga nearonessa, þe him onbecumað, Gode swa fulfremedlice areccan, ne his mildheortnesse biddan, swa he mæg mid þillicum sealmum 7 mid oþrum swilcum.
Gyf þu ælce dæge þine tidsangas wel asingst, ne þearft ðu næfre to helle, 7 eac on þisse worulde þu hæfst þe gedefe lif.
7 gyf ðu on hwilcum earfeðum byst 7 to Gode clypast, he ðe miltsað 7 eac tiþað, þonne þu hine bitsð. Amen (Ælfwine’s Prayerbook, no. 53).12

Short as this text is, it nevertheless gives a full programme for the monk or nun’s morning prayers, to be said on Sundays (1), or simply every day (3). The reader is instructed to call upon the Trinity (1) and sing the Benedicite, Gloria in excelsis, Creed and Paternoster (2), to say a vernacular penitential prayer (4), and, on Fridays, to contemplate the Passion (7) in private (6) whilst singing a psalm of penitence (5). The writer subsequently comments that one should also sing the Hours every day (9)—presumably referring to the communal prayer of the Offices, rather than to this private morning devotion—and that one may call upon God and receive help from him in any time of trouble (10).

In the course of this prayer programme, the compiler remarks that it is ‘with these psalms and with other such’ that one is best able to express one’s sufferings to God and ask his mercy (8). Although Günzel reports no analogues for the ‘Directions for Private Devotion’, this sentence is in fact a closely translated quotation from a Carolingian prayer guide known as De laude psalmorum. This text is a short treatise which teaches its reader how to pray for his or her own personal needs using the words of the psalms. It appears at the beginning of the ninth-century prayer collection known as De psalmorum usu, which was once attributed to Alcuin but subsequently shown by André Wilmart not to be his work.13 Wilmart nevertheless accepted De laude psalmorum to be the genuine work of Alcuin, a judgement with which Donald A. Bullough agreed, as has Jonathan Black, who has undertaken an intensive study of this prayer guide, including a comparative edition of the text.14 Stephan Waldhoff, by contrast, has followed Jean Chazelas in arguing against this attribution.15 More than two hundred complete or incomplete copies of De laude psalmorum survive, dating from the ninth to the fifteenth centuries and mostly originating from continental Europe.16 The one surviving manuscript from pre-Conquest England which includes a Latin excerpt from this text will be discussed below.

De laude psalmorum is not a complete prayer programme to be followed from beginning to end, but instead it allows the reader to choose which parts to follow according to his or her circumstances. Aside from a brief introduction and epilogue, the text is composed of eight short sections, each of which discusses a different reason why the reader might wish to pray to God, giving a short selection of psalms to sing when in this particular situation. It is the second of these sections which is of relevance to Ælfwine’s Prayerbook:
Si vis orare, permitte mentem tuam in virtute psalmorum quorum initium est: Ad te, Domine, levavi animam meam; et Deus, in te speravi, Domine; necnon Inclina, Domine; et Domine Deus, in adiutorium meum; Deus, in nomine tuo; Deus misereatur nobis; Exaudi, Domine, iustitiam meam; et nullatenus potes tua propria lingua nec humano sensu tam perfecte miseriam tuam ac tribulationem angustiamque diversarum temptationum explicare et illius misericordiam implorare quam in his psalmis et ceteris his similibus (De laude psalmorum, lines 156–70).17 The second half of this paragraph (beginning ‘nullatenus potes …’) is clearly the immediate source of line 8 of the prayer guide in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook. As shown above, after instructing the reader to sing Psalm 66 on Fridays, the writer of this guide comments:
Ne mæg ænig mann on his agen geþeode þa geswinc 7 þara costnunga nearonessa, þe him onbecumað, Gode swa fulfremedlice areccan, ne his mildheortnesse biddan, swa he mæg mid þillicum sealmum 7 mid oþrum swilcum (Ælfwine’s Prayerbook, no. 53.8).18 The Old English text is a very close translation of the Latin, indeed an exact one, except that it omits the words ‘nec humano sensu’ and has been adapted from the second to the third person. This is difficult to explain, particularly as both De laude psalmorum and the rest of the text in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook address their readers directly in the second person. Black observes that some manuscripts of De laude psalmorum do in fact give ‘potest’ or ‘poterit’ for ‘potes’, but in these instances the subject of the sentence is ‘tua propria lingua’ or ‘humanus sensus’ rather than the reader of the treatise.19 In Ælfwine’s Prayerbook, by contrast, the meaning of the sentence is preserved through the slight alteration of the text to ‘[n]e mæg ænig mann’ (‘no man can’).

It is not known where Scribe F of Ælfwine’s Prayerbook came upon this quotation, nor whether he or she knew De laude psalmorum in full. Of the many manuscripts containing De laude psalmorum, or parts of it, which Black lists, only one was written in pre-Conquest England, and this dates from a little later than Ælfwine’s Prayerbook. London, British Library Cotton Tiberius C. vi, known as the Tiberius Psalter, is a Winchester manuscript probably dating to the 1060s, which begins with thirty folios of miscellaneous texts.20 Of particular interest is a text on fols. 21v–22v, which outlines a plan for morning prayer using psalms and the prayer ‘Omnipotens sempiterne deus’.21 This is immediately followed, on fols. 22v–23r, by a short excerpt from De laude psalmorum: the eighth use of the psalms, in which Beati immaculati is recommended for those who wish to occupy themselves with praising God and with his commands; plus the epilogue, which teaches that the psalms include every kind of divine scripture and teaching for those who read them carefully.22 After this extract appears a confessional ordo for use with a priest, ending on fol. 27r–v with a condensed version of De laude psalmorum: a list of all the reasons given in the full treatise for singing the psalms, followed by another list of the psalms which should be sung for help every day.23

The extracts from De laude psalmorum in these two manuscripts, and in particular the summary in Tiberius C. vi, suggest that at least one complete copy of the psalm devotional is likely to have existed in eleventh-century England, even if the compilers of these two texts did not draw upon it directly. Indeed, the existence of a quotation from De laude psalmorum in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook demonstrates that this text may have been better known in England at this time than has so far been thought. The extraction of individual sections of the psalm programme suggests that Anglo-Saxon scribes used De laude psalmorum exactly as was intended: not as a single prayer programme which should be followed in full by every reader, but as a list of recommendations for readers with different reasons for wanting to pray. By selecting the parts which they presumably considered to be most important or most relevant, the compilers of the texts in Tiberius C. vi and Ælfwine’s Prayerbook used De laude psalmorum in order to create entirely new programmes for morning prayer using the psalms.

In particular, it is the prayer guide in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook which demonstrates the importance of the vernacular language in this period, as it uses Old English alongside Latin not only for explaining the importance of prayer, but also for prayer itself. Although only one sentence from De laude psalmorum was included in Ælfwine’s Prayerbook, this selection is in itself significant. From the earlier psalm treatise, the anonymous compiler chose the part which teaches that the best kind of prayer, the most effective way of articulating one’s trials and temptations in both communal and private devotion, was to be found in the words of the psalms. For the compilers of both texts, it was in these words that monks and nuns could express to God how great their struggles were, and how much they needed his mercy.24

Rockford, IL, 1989). ‘(1) Every Sunday, pray in the name of the Trinity, that is the Father, Son, and the Holy Spirit. (2) And sing ‘Bless the Lord’, ‘Glory to God in the Highest’, ‘I believe in God’, and ‘Our Father’ to the praise of Christ; then all the week will go the better for you. (3) You could get used to singing it every day, when you first wake up. (4) And then say to God Almighty, ‘For your great mercy, and for the power of these words of God, have mercy on me, and grant me forgiveness of the sins I have committed, and protection against future ones, and your blessings in all things, and especially my soul’s rest in eternal life, and your mercy forever.’ (5) And every Friday, think to stretch yourself out onto the earth with thanks to God, and sing ‘May God have mercy on us’. (6) And do this secretly, where you are alone. (7) And think that he suffered greatly on that day for all humankind. (8) No man can tell God so effectively, in his own language, of the hardship and oppression of the temptations which come to him, nor ask his mercy, as he can with these psalms and with other such. (9) If you sing your Hours well every day, you need never go to hell, and in this world too you will have a good life. (10) And if you are in any kind of trouble and call to God, he will have mercy on you and also give to you, when you ask him. Amen.’
